Matilda

Roald Dahl

What's the story doing?

Who tells it

An all-knowing narrator who constantly comments and guides us, taking the children's side against unfair adults.

What we experience

We follow a brilliant girl who uses her intelligence and magical powers to defeat cruel adults and find a loving home.

How it feels

We feel conspiratorial with the narrator, laughing at ridiculous adults while cheering for Matilda's victories.

Exposition

Adults are hilariously blind to their own children's faults and Matilda's brilliance, setting up a world where grown-ups can't be trusted to see clearly.

Rising Action

Children must warn and protect each other because the school system is run by a genuinely dangerous tyrant who uses physical violence.

Climax

Matilda's supernatural powers represent how exceptional intelligence can become a force that challenges and defeats oppressive systems.

Falling Action

Intelligence works strategically and secretly, planning carefully before striking against injustice.

Resolution

Children can choose their own families when biological families fail them, and true belonging comes from love rather than blood.

No devices available.

Narration

The all-knowing narrator lets us see inside everyone's thoughts while constantly commenting to build solidarity between reader and child against foolish adults.

Devices

The conspiratorial, child-championing tone makes us feel like we're part of a secret rebellion, laughing at adult incompetence while supporting Matilda's intelligence.

Together

Together: we experience the story as fellow conspirators in a child's righteous war against unfair authority, making her victory feel like our victory too.

This pattern is called

Intrusive Advocacy

The narrator intrudes constantly to advocate for children's rights and guide us toward supporting Matilda's rebellion.

Your thesis

Who tells it an all-knowing, child-championing narrator
What's revealed the systematic failures of adult authority
Story type a magical rebellion story
Larger meaning children's right to choose loving families over biological ones
Method through conspiratorial humor that makes readers allies in the fight

Through an all-knowing, child-championing narrator who reveals the systematic failures of adult authority, Dahl creates a magical rebellion story that argues for children's right to choose loving families over biological ones, using conspiratorial humor that makes readers allies in the fight against unfair power.
